data.title: DeprecationWarning: `node --inspect --debug-brk` is deprecated
data.body:
Since VSCode version 1.15.0 F5 (starting debug) prints out the following message:
```
(node:31245) [DEP0062] DeprecationWarning: `node --inspect --debug-brk` is deprecated. Please use `node --inspect-brk` instead.
```
Any ideas how to prevent this warning?

---------------------------------------------------
Project/System details:

data.title: Add when clause support to command icons
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.16.0-insider (b73b7df1290d0fe66ca8b8060743711a327af622, 2017-08-14T05:16:07.578Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.16257
---

Currently it is difficult to "simulate" the changing of an icon of a command. Since the api doesn't allow changing the icon directly, it has to be simulated by using extra commands and contexts.

For example, in GitLens I've recently added a new "feature" to show a sort of progress indicator on the `gitlens.toggleFileBlame` command while I am computing the blame annotations (the icon pulses), and then once completed I change the blame icon to be in an "on" state to indicate that the blame is active (the icon turns orange).

To accomplish this I have to create 3 commands, the original `gitlens.toggleFileBlame` command for the `off` state, `gitlens.computingFileAnnotations` command which is a no-op for the `progress` state, and `gitlens.clearFileAnnotations` for the `on` state. You can see definition of 3 commands [here](https://github.com/eamodio/vscode-gitlens/blob/00cdd2e375e77c5cf5339d84c0287be30a80971b/package.json#L812-L838). And the usage of those commands can be seen [here](https://github.com/eamodio/vscode-gitlens/blob/00cdd2e375e77c5cf5339d84c0287be30a80971b/package.json#L1253-L1268)

Instead of having 3 command for this, I would much rather have been able to have a single command:
```json
{
    "command": "gitlens.toggleFileBlame",
    "title": "Toggle File Blame Annotations",
    "category": "GitLens",
    "icon": {
        "dark": "images/dark/git-icon.svg",
        "light": "images/light/git-icon.svg",
        "when": !gitlens:annotationStatus
    },
    "icon": {
        "dark": "images/dark/git-icon-progress.svg",
        "light": "images/light/git-icon-progress.svg",
        "when": gitlens:annotationStatus == computing
    },
    "icon": {
        "dark": "images/dark/git-icon-orange.svg",
        "light": "images/light/git-icon-orange.svg",
        "when": gitlens:annotationStatus == computed
    }
}
```

That way I wouldn't need to switch the commands out in each menu (currently I'm being lazy and only doing it on the editor/title navigation), the keyboard shortcuts show up as expect, and I don't need to register extra commands that I don't actually need.

- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
bazel-code|Dev|0.1.8
path-intellisense|chr|1.4.2
vscode-svgviewer|css|1.4.2
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
gitlens|eam|4.3.3
tslint|eg2|0.17.0
git-project-manager|fel|1.3.2
auto-rename-tag|for|0.0.14
contextualduplicate|laf|0.2.0
debugger-for-chrome|msj|3.1.7
vscode-subword-navigation|ow|1.1.5
Align|ste|0.2.0
rewrap|stk|1.4.2
clang-format|xav|1.5.0
vscode-proto3|zxh|0.1.2

(3 theme extensions excluded)


---

**Steps to Reproduce:**

1. Use `escape` in a chorded keybinding:
```json
    {
        "key": "escape s",
        "command": "workbench.action.showCommands"
    },
    {
        "key": "escape a",
        "command": "workbench.action.quickOpen"
    },
```
2. Open the Find widget (Cmd+F) or trigger autocomplete (type `window.addEv` in a JavaScript file)
3. Hit the Escape key to close it.

**Expected Results:**
The autocomplete or find widget closes.

**Actual Results:**
Status bar says `(Escape) was pressed; waiting for second key of chord`.

**Note**:
I map Caps to Escape, so I can chord Caps+A and Caps+S to common commands.  I've used the same workflow in Sublime for a long time, and I've never had this problem.

Reproduces without extensions: **Yes**

data.title: [Debug] Unexpected end of JSON input. Stopping the debug adapter.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.15.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 10

We're developing java debugger. And we want to send the stdout message of the target debuggee console to vscode debug console using OutputEvent. Sometimes when the output messages are not utf8 characters but Chinese characters, DA will terminate with message box `Unexpected end of JSON input. Stopping the debug adapter.`, but send the `disconnect` request at a new debug session. This would cause the old debugger not to know when to release it's jvm resource.

See the DA pipeline below:
[[RESPONSE]]
{"event":"output","body":{"category":"stdout","output":"\r\n","type":"output"},"seq":31,"type":"event"}
**[DA terminated current debug session's communication channel and popup a message box "Unexpected end of JSON input. Stopping the debug adapter."]**
**[After that, DA will launch a new debug session with a disconnect request]**
[REQUEST]
{"command":"disconnect","arguments":{"restart":false},"type":"request","seq":23}
[[RESPONSE]]
{"success":true,"request_seq":23,"command":"disconnect","body":{},"seq":1,"type":"response"}

Expected:
DA should be able to handle the non utf8 chars in OutputEvent. At least, even if it throws exception and terminated unexpectedly, it should send the last `disconnect` request at the end of current debug session instead of new debug session. That would give the debugger a chance to clean up its resource.

data.title: The option editor.autoIndent makes VSCode behave strangely.
data.body:
<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: v1.15.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a (typescript) file like:

    ```ts
    let test: string[] = [

        "a",

        "b",

        "c"
    ];
    ```

2. Copy following text

    ```ts
    ,

        "b",

        "c"
    ```

3. Paste it after `"c"`, we will get:

    ```ts
    const OK_CMDS: string[] = [

        "a",

        "b",

        "c",
        // Here is 4 spaces
            "b", // Here is 4 spaces more indentation
        // Here is 4 spaces
            "c" // Here is 4 spaces more indentation
    ];
    ```

And before v1.15.0, we should get

```ts
const OK_CMDS: string[] = [

    "a",

    "b",

    "c",
// here is no spaces
    "b", // here should be only 4 spaces as indentation
// here is no spaces
    "c" // here should be only 4 spaces as indentation
];
```

I search for **indent** in settings, and found the option `editor.autoIndent`. I set it to `false` and then all behavior is well, as v1.14.x did. Thus I wonder, what does it mean? This option makes VSCode behave so strangely as Eclipse does.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: A new feature requirement: The tab head of the text editor for the default file of a module

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Hello guys, 

I'm a Web Developer. Given the ES 6 Module (for Web page) and Rust Module (for Web Assembly), the entry file name under the module directory is senseless. For example, "index.js" is for ES; and "mod.rs" is for Rust.

If either of them is displayed in the Tab head of the text editor, I won't acquire sufficient information about what file I'm editing. It's frustrating to see a lot of "index.js" tab heads above the text editor, because the file name can't embody what it really is.

As a result, I suggest that the directory name of the "index.js" and "mod.rs" file is displayed in the tab head, which is helpful to the editors.

data.title: Slack "team" for vscode extensions
data.body:
Now that slack allows for permanent (though revocable) invite links it would be great if there was a "dedicated" slack for extension authors and of course the vscode team should they be willing ;)

I currently have one setup explicitly for [GitLens](https://join.slack.com/t/vscode-gitlens/shared_invite/MjIxOTgxNDE3NzM0LTE1MDE2Nzk1MTgtMjkwMmZjMzcxNQ), but I think it would be great to have more community around the extensions in a common place. Although if the vscode team isn't interested in "owning" this but other extension authors think this is a good idea, I could rename & repurpose the GitLens slack into a general vscode extensions one.

Just throwing this out there :)

data.title: Suggest should not force tokenization in very large files
data.body:
Related to https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/21564 and https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/30181 .

When we open a large file (or whose tokenization takes a long time), any feature that requires accurate token information runs `model.forceTokenization` and it blocks the UI, including

* [x] Paste (Auto Indent checks token info)
* [x] Enter (Enter rules or Indentation)
* [x] Type 
   * [x] (Auto Indent or electric chars)
   * [x] Suggest (Suggestion and Snippet)
   * [ ] Others ?

Paste/Enter/Type relies on indentation/enter rules, right now I skipped the smart features if the tokenization is not yet ready for selections. But speaking of suggestions, some suggestion provider (like snippet) requires language id at position, some (quickSuggestions) requires token info, these two force tokenization for selection, which would lead to UI blocking.

Enable quick suggestion and snippet (default)

![typeblock](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/876920/29296426-09b35b64-810f-11e7-8b9b-3979dd19e94e.gif)
 
Disable both of them by `"editor.quickSuggestions": false, "editor.snippetSuggestions": "none"`

![typenoblock](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/876920/29296444-3bb45f14-810f-11e7-8bf2-09a334b2cffb.gif)

Any component that requires token/language info can lead to the UI blocking when users open a large file and modify real quick. As we increase the file size limit for tokenization, this may happen more often. cc @alexandrudima @jrieken @ramya-rao-a

data.title: Detect autofetch credential prompt and show explanation
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14.2
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.6

**Steps to Reproduce:**

Have a VSCode window open to a git repo that SSH authentication

**Expected Result:**

I don't notice VSCode is open until I try to use it.

**Actual Result:**

I keep getting password prompts that ask for my SSH passphrase, with no context of what app spawned them, or why my password might be needed.  Your Twitter account [recommended disabling `autofetch` to workaround](https://twitter.com/VisualStudio/status/897200657870053376).

**Request:**

We certainly shouldn't be training users to type credentials into prompts that appear with no explanation, and security-conscious users will hopefully be skeptical of such prompts (or apps that cause them).

VSCode ought to detect when an automatic/background git operation has spawned a credential window (perhaps by measuring when git operations take too long or cancel unexpectedly) and show an explanation of:

1. why VSCode tried to use the git credentials
2. how to disable that behavior.

**Related issues:**
- #23951
- #26573
- #26441
- #11918

data.title: Find on big files does not highlight every match
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.0
- OS Version: Linux Mint 18.1

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open "very big" dataset (mine have 50625 lines, and sorry, can't distribute)
2. Perform a search on this very big dataset.

The find window will show "1 of 999+" instead of highlighting every match. The minimap also show only a few results, although there's at least one match every single line.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5909442/29290708-7cd41630-8117-11e7-948e-5bcac3c71903.png)

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

Observations:
If I click to navigate to the previous match, it will show `? of 999+` but it work perfectly, setting the cursor on the correct position on the last line of the "very big" file, but still don't highligthing the match.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5909442/29290806-c9ff3dc2-8117-11e7-8d16-b774d2a8bfe7.png)

it opens fine and it's way faster than sublime text (except highlighting SQL which is not important for such a big file)

but when i try to save the file it says : "Invalid string length"

VSCode : Version 1.15.0 (1.15.0)

data.title: Fix tabbing in trees
data.body:
PR 2: Electric Boogaloo

I changed the tab index to -1 instead of not setting it at all so it can still be focusable which fixes the quick navigate feature. 

- Changes the tabbing in quick-open-tree so that the actionbar items can be reached in one tab instead of two (where the first tab was to focus the whole tree).
- Keeps quickopen open when pressing up or down with an action bar item focused

Fixes https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/31835 and https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/31836

data.title: Command editor.emmet.action.matchingPair not found on macOS
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.0 (8b95971d8cccd3afd86b35d4a0e098c189294ff2, 2017-08-09T20:06:21.685Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
gitignore|cod|0.5.0
hg|mrc|1.1.5
vscode-apache|mrm|1.1.1

---

Keyboard shortcut command `editor.emmet.action.matchingPair` fails using v1.15.0 on macOS. I have added the same shortcut on a Windows machine and it appears to work fine. Error message:

>[warn] command 'editor.emmet.action.matchingPair' not found

The command is available and works normally from the command palette ('Emmet: Go to Matching Pair').

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Be using macOS
2. Add a custom keyboard shortcut with command `editor.emmet.action.matchingPair`
3. Attempt to use that shortcut in the Editor

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: PHP Multi line comment leaking into entire file
data.body: - VSCode Version: Version 1.15.0 - OS Version: OSX 10.11.5 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open a new PHP file 2. Write a simple one line function 3. Write a multi-line comment above it Using the /** */ format. 4. Describe a parameter using the @param (TYPE) paradigm. By doing this, the comment highlighting will leak and incorrectly highlight the rest of the file. Reproduces without extensions: Yes Example of the issue Example without parenthesis
